Interstellar is another movie where Christopher Nolan hits the ball out of the park. Between the absolute beauty that is the music by Hans Zimmer, and the absolute top-tier acting performance that Matthew McConaughey delivers (especially those yells and cries my god), it is a must-watch for any fan of space exploration. Christopher Nolan's Sci-fi adventure is also surprisingly more science than fiction. The way he uses no sound when you're looking at the movie from space is peak genius. My only real negative is that the movie's length is a bit tedious, and while watching it the first hour is definitely the hardest to get through due to massive exposition dumps. But when you finish the movie, it does feel very complete and everything comes full circle. The pacing is near exceptional, however, do pay attention to details the movie drops because like my algebra class, this story flies like a rocket. Now onto spoiler territory, the concept of wormholes and time dilation is stellar, not pun intended. The way Cooper just sacrifices himself by going into the tesseract felt like the scene was shooting bullets at my heart. And the pure emotion Matthew McConaughey is putting into his voice when he's telling Murphy to stay could make the toughest grown men cry, I'm sure of it. Overall, if you're looking for an emotional space movie, and you're willing to sit through nearly 3 hours of adventure, Interstellar is the perfect watch.

It allows us to go beyond the limit of our knowledge regarding space and time and travelling through them and to think deeper than just what is on our own planet. You just have to be willing to look up at the sky and wander and be willing to explore.

There so much I want to stay about this movie but nothing amount of words can get my point across of how much this movie changed me and my perspective on life and humanity itself. The idea of time has always been fascinating to me and now I feel so overwhelmed with curiosity over the matter that I don‚Äôt know what to do. A movie has never left me in such shambles as this has. Let me get this straight-this movie is a cinematic MASTERPIECE. The story, the music and score, the acting...everything is SO WELL DONE. In my personal opinion Matthew McConaughey completely carried this movie. He delivered such a remarkable and jaw dropping performance that left me speechless at the end. Are we even going to talk about the scene where he watches the videos from his kids?! I was in awe-and honestly a little unsettled-the whole scene because of how real his performance felt, as if he truly was a father mourning the lost years of his kids' lives, like Cooper. The way he could tap into such raw emotion, make himself cry, and deliver such an eerily authentic portrayal was almost frightening in its realism. He also had such a great onscreen bond with Mckenzie Foy that even left me in tears as we watched their relationship and bond unfold and eventually save humanity. There were many aha! Moments and the adrenaline was indeed pumping as I was mesmerized and pulled deeply into concentration on the movie. So why is this movie missing two stars? Don't get me wrong Christopher Nolan completely delivered and made me feel all the emotions he wanted viewers to feel, and while I did enjoy it, it is not a movie to take lightly. There is a lot of informational thrown at you and a lot of words the average movie watcher might not understand. I get it, it's a sci-fi movie, and a great one at that, but the end completely messed with my brain and had me scavaging the internet and Youtube for explanations. Because of this, I feel like this movie is one that you really can't talk to your friends while watching or get up to go to the bathroom since you will miss critical information. Also, there were some scenes and monologues that felt a little too long and didn't do much to drive the story forward. Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed Interstellar. It's an incredibly captivating and emotional film that kept me hooked from start to finish. While it can be a bit confusing at times and definitely a lot to take in, I would absolutely recommend it to anyone who loves thought-provoking, visually stunning movies.

I‚Äôve spent a full decade anticipating the return of Interstellar to the big screen in its purest form‚Äî70mm IMAX‚Äîand let me say, it surpassed every grand expectation I carried with me. There‚Äôs something profoundly immersive about watching Christopher Nolan‚Äôs vision unfold in that large-format glory, where every star and ripple in space feels tactile and alive. This isn‚Äôt just a sci-fi movie it‚Äôs a soul-stirring journey through the best and worst of humanity, a meditation on love, time, sacrifice, and hope. After all these years, the visuals still hold an unmatched sense of wonder. Seeing the iconic scenes‚Äîlike the spaceship poised delicately against Saturn‚Äôs rings, or the breathtaking approach to Gargantua‚Äîon an enormous screen made me catch my breath as if I were an explorer staring into the unknown. But it wasn‚Äôt just the cinematic spectacle that struck me it was the surge of emotions that washed over me again and again. From the exhilaration of liftoff to the anxiety of clock-ticking planetary landings, from the heartache of impossible choices to the awe of cosmic revelations, my emotions soared and crashed like waves on a distant shore. In particular, the relationships at the film‚Äôs core struck a deeper chord this time around. The dialogue between Cooper and Murph felt even more resonant, the idea of love transcending time and space richer than ever. By the time the credits rolled, I was left overwhelmed‚Äîgrateful that this story had returned in such pristine quality, astonished by how it still moved me to tears, and comforted by the timeless human truths it illuminates. It took me a decade to see Interstellar again this way, and it was worth every second of that wait. This re-release stands as a reminder that truly great cinema doesn‚Äôt just entertain it shakes you to your core. If you have the chance to witness it in 70mm IMAX, don‚Äôt hesitate. This is a film that will remind you why you fell in love with the magic of movies in the first place.
